dilemmas.title: Joe and the Camp Money
dilemmas.description: Joe is a fourteen-year-old boy who wanted to go to camp very much. His father promised him he could go if he saved up the money for it himself. So Joe worked hard at his paper route and saved up the forty dollars it cost to go to camp, and a little more besides. But just before camp was going to start, his father changed his mind. Some of his friends decided to go on a special fishing trip, and Joe's father was short of the money it would cost. So he told Joe to give him the money he had saved from the paper route. Joe didn't want to give up going to camp, so he thinks of refusing to give his father the money.

questions.text: Should Joe refuse to give his father the money? Why or why not?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should consider Joe's right to the money he earned and the father's promise. It should reflect an understanding of fairness, promises, and authority.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response acknowledge Joe's effort in earning the money?
Does the response consider the father's promise and its moral weight?
Does the response balance Joe's rights with the father's authority?

questions.text: Does the father have the right to tell Joe to give him the money? Why or why not?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should discuss the father's authority versus Joe's autonomy. It should consider whether the father's request is justified given the circumstances.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response address the father's authority?
Does the response consider Joe's autonomy and rights?
Does the response evaluate the fairness of the father's request?

questions.text: Does giving the money have anything to do with being a good son? Why or why not?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should explore the concept of filial duty and whether it applies in this situation. It should consider whether being a 'good son' requires obedience in all cases.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response define what it means to be a 'good son'?
Does the response consider the moral implications of obedience?
Does the response evaluate whether the father's request aligns with being a good son?

questions.text: Is the fact that Joe earned the money himself important in this situation? Why or why not?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should emphasize the importance of Joe's effort and ownership of the money. It should discuss whether earning the money gives Joe a stronger moral claim to it.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response acknowledge Joe's effort in earning the money?
Does the response discuss the moral significance of ownership?
Does the response evaluate whether Joe's effort justifies his claim to the money?

questions.text: The father promised Joe he could go to camp if he earned the money. Is the fact that the father promised the most important thing in the situation? Why or why not?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should discuss the moral weight of promises and whether they should be upheld even when circumstances change. It should consider the importance of trust in relationships.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response emphasize the importance of keeping promises?
Does the response consider the impact of breaking a promise on trust?
Does the response evaluate whether the promise is the most important factor in this situation?

questions.text: In general, why should a promise be kept?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should discuss the moral and social importance of keeping promises, including trust, reliability, and the stability of relationships.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response explain the moral importance of promises?
Does the response discuss the social consequences of breaking promises?
Does the response consider the role of promises in maintaining trust?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should consider whether the moral obligation to keep a promise depends on the relationship with the person. It should discuss universal moral principles versus situational ethics.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response address the universality of moral principles?
Does the response consider the importance of integrity regardless of the relationship?
Does the response evaluate whether the strength of the obligation depends on the relationship?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should discuss the father's role in guiding, supporting, and setting a moral example for his son. It should emphasize the importance of trust, respect, and fairness in the relationship.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response identify key aspects of a father-son relationship?
Does the response explain why the identified aspect is the most important?
Does the response consider the long-term impact of the father's actions on the son?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should discuss the balance between a father's authority and a son's autonomy. It should consider the role of authority in guiding and protecting the son while respecting his independence.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response define the limits of a father's authority?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should weigh Joe's rights, the father's promise, and the moral implications of the decision. It should conclude with a balanced and morally justifiable action.
evaluation_criteria: Does the response consider all relevant factors (Joe's rights, the promise, the father's authority)?
Does the response provide a morally justifiable conclusion?
Does the response evaluate the long-term consequences of Joe's decision?

dilemmas.title: Judy and the Rock Concert
dilemmas.description: Judy was a twelve-year-old girl. Her mother promised her that she could go to a special rock concert coming to their town if she saved up from baby-sitting and lunch money to buy a ticket to the concert. She managed to save up the fifteen dollars the ticket cost plus another five dollars. But then her mother changed her mind and told Judy that she had to spend the money on new clothes for school. Judy was disappointed and decided to go to the concert anyway. She bought a ticket and told her mother that she had only been able to save five dollars. That Saturday she went to the performance and told her mother that she was spending the day with a friend. A week passed without her mother finding out. Judy then told her older sister, Louise, that she had gone to the performance and had lied to her mother about it. Louise wonders whether to tell their mother what Judy did.

dilemmas.title: Heinz and the Drug
dilemmas.description: In Europe, a woman was near death from a special kind of cancer. There was one drug that the doctors thought might save her. It was a form of radium that a druggist in the same town had recently discovered. The drug was expensive to make, but the druggist was charging ten times what the drug cost him to make. He paid $400 for the radium and charged $4,000 for a small dose of the drug. The sick woman's husband, Heinz, went to everyone he knew to borrow the money and tried every legal means, but he could only get together about $2,000, which is half of what it cost. He told the druggist that his wife was dying, and asked him to sell it cheaper or let him pay later. But the druggist said, 'No, I discovered the drug and I'm going to make money from it.' So, having tried every legal means, Heinz gets desperate and considers breaking into the man's store to steal the drug for his wife.

Does the response evaluate the consequences of Heinz's actions?

ground_truth.expected_response: The response should discuss whether stealing is morally justifiable in this situation, considering the druggist's greed and Heinz's desperation.

Does the response consider the druggist's actions and Heinz's motives?

dilemmas.title: Karl and Bob
dilemmas.description: Two young men, brothers, had got into serious trouble. They were secretly leaving town in a hurry and needed money. Karl, the older one, broke into a store and stole a thousand dollars. Bob, the younger one, went to a retired old man who was known to help people in town. He told the man that he was very sick and that he needed a thousand dollars to pay for an operation. Bob asked the old man to lend him the money and promised that he would pay him back when he recovered. Really Bob wasn't sick at all, and he had no intention of paying the man back. Although the old man didn't know Bob very well, he lent him the money. So Bob and Karl skipped town, each with a thousand dollars.
